(Right) the corresponding size distributions of Pt particles. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Pt 4f XPS spectra of selected TS-1 based catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Ti 2p XPS spectra of selected TS-1 based catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 DRIFT spectra for the adsorption of CO on reduced Pt-TS-1-based catalysts at room temperature. (a) IM-1, (b) EG-1, (c)EG-2, and (d) EG-3. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Catalytic performance of the TS-1-based catalyst for the dehydrogenation of n-butane. (a) IM-1, (b) EG-1, (c) EG-2, and (d) EG-3. Reacrion condition: 0.10 g, n-butane : H2: Ar = 5: 1: 94, 50 mL·min−1·. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Catalytic stabilities of the TS-1-based catalyst during the dehydrogenation of n-butane. State Key Laboratory of Multiphase Complex Systems Institute of Process Engineering Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing PR China Graphical abstract A series of catalysts in which platinum was supported on the crystalline pure titanium silicalite (TS-1) were prepared using two different loading methods, namely, an ethylene glycol (EG) reduction method and the conventional incipient wetness impregnation (IM) technique. Various characterization techniques were used to study the effect of the loading method on the physicochemical and morphological properties of the prepared catalysts. Also the effect of the platinum-loading method on the dehydrogenation of n-butane was investigated in a fixed-bed reactor. The results show that the EG method favors the formation of a more-concentrated Pt dispersion, which results in much better catalytic activities for the selective formation of butenes and butadiene (> 97 %). This phenomenon is interpreted by carrying out density functional theory (DFT) calculations with focus on the relationship between the coverage of n-butane on Pt surface and the activation barrier for the first CH bond cleavage. Keywords N-butane Direct dehydrogenation Pre-reduction DFT Particle size 1 Introduction The catalytic dehydrogenation of n-butane is a highly important reaction for production of butenes (n-butene, cis-2-butene, and trans-2-butene) and butadiene, which are the raw materials of synthetic rubbers, plastics, and other valuable chemical products [1,2]. There are two types of dehydrogenation: (i) oxidative dehydrogenation [3,4] and (ii) direct dehydrogenation [5–7]. Oxidative dehydrogenation requires an oxidant, such as oxygen, carbon dioxide, or nitrous oxide, to be introduced, which easily leads to a deeper n-butane oxidation; consequently, selectivity for the target products is limited by side reactions [8–10]. By comparison, direct dehydrogenation exhibits a competitive selectivity for the target products, i.e. butenes and butadiene. However, this process requires high temperatures to achieve sensible yields and hence suffers catalyst deactivation. Since butane dehydrogenation is a structure sensitive reaction [11–13], controlling the particle size of Pt could improve the activities of the catalysts at relatively low temperatures. In this case, the deactivation could be inhibited. Many kinds of Pt support have been tested for n-butane dehydrogenation process, including MgO [1], SiO2 [6], TiO2 [9], ZrO2 [15], and Al2O3 [2,7,14]. Catalytic performance is known to be significantly affected by the electronic interactions between the metal and the support during heterogeneous catalysis [11,12]. In some cases, the strong mutual interaction could stabilize the size of metal particles during catalytic reactions. Simultaneously, the type or morphology of the support is also a promising method for improving the catalytic performances of Pt-based catalysts. For instance, in the dehydrogenation process the use of structured mesoporous (silica foam [17], SBA-15 [8] and MCM-41 [16]) silica can stabilize the metal nanoparticles through the well-defined pores. In recent years, the TS-1 titanium silicalite molecular sieve has been considered to be one of the most promising supports for Pt particles due to its highly dispersed and isolated Ti [18,19]. TS-1 is very mechanically strong and has a high specific surface area and pore structure suitable for loading active components. More importantly, its high thermal/hydrothermal stability [20] motivates us to investigate TS-1 supported Pt particles towards n-butane dehydrogenation. Conventional preparation techniques based on wet impregnation and the chemical reduction of metal precursors, typically by gas-phase H2, often do not provide adequate control of particle shape and size [22]. Modified methods have been developed recently, and materials that are more-active than commercial Pt-based catalysts have been produced. In all cases, the connectivity between the Pt particles and the surface of the support, and the dispersion of the Pt particles was found to be important [23,24]. In this paper, we use two different preparation techniques to prepare TS-1 supported Pt nanoparticles towards n-butane dehydrogenation. Specifically, a series of TS-1 based catalysts was prepared by the conversional wet impregnation method as well as the ethylene glycol (EG) prereduction technique. The effect of the platinum-loading method on the dehydrogenation of n-butane was investigated in a fixed-bed reactor. N2-adsorption/desorption, X-ray diffractometry (XRD), diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were used to study the effects of the various preparation methods on the physicochemical and morphological properties of the prepared samples. The location of the platinum, the acidities of the catalysts, and their catalytic performance toward the dehydrogenation of n-butane were investigated. Furthermore, the relationship between the particle size and the activity was studied by DFT calculations. 2 Catalyst synthesis 2.1 Catalyst preparation The TS-1 support was synthesized according to the traditional hydrothermal method with the required Si/Ti molar ratio [22]. First, specific amounts of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) and tetrabutyl titanate (TBOT) were dissolved in an aqueous solution of tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH). The mixture was stirred in ice water for 1 h and then heated to 70 °C for 3 h, after which isopropanol (IPA) was added and the mixture was stirred for 1 h. The molar composition of the final gel was: 1 SiO2: 0.02 TiO2:4 IPA: 0.3 TPAOH: 35 H2O. Second, the solution was subjected to hydrothermal crystallization at 170 °C for 4 d. After repeated washing and drying, the precursor was calcined in air at 550 °C to produce the 100 nm TS-1 zeolite. The IM-1 catalyst was prepared by the traditional impregnation method, as reported in the literature [4,10]. Pt-TS-1-EG catalysts were prepared by an ethylene glycol prereduction (EG) method. An aqueous solution of H2PtCl6·6H2O was added to a solution of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) in ethylene glycol with stirring. The mixed solution was then heated at 140 °C and for 2 h under reflux. The TS-1 support was then added to the mixture, ultrasonicated, and dried at 120 °C for 12 h. The mixture was then calcined at 500 °C for 4 h to obtain the Pt-TS-1-EG catalyst. The size distributions of Pt particles were investigated by varying the molar ratio of Pt to PVP. These catalysts are referred to as “EG-1” (Pt:PVP = 1:20), “EG-2” (Pt:PVP = 1:50), and “EG-3” (Pt:PVP = 1:70). 2.2 Catalyst characterization The crystalline phases of the TS-1-based catalysts were examined by XRD (Rigaku, D-MAX2500-PC) at 50 kV and 100 mA using Cu-K radiation (λ = 1.541 Å). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas, pore volumes, and average pore diameters of the catalysts were measured by N2-adsorption/desorption experiments using a BELSORP-mini II (BEL Japan) instrument. The size distributions of the Pt particles on the support were determined by TEM using a JEOL 2100 instrument. The Pt particles were assumed to be spherical and the average particle size was calculated according to the equation: d = ∑ni d i 3/∑ni d i 2. XPS was performed on a Thermo Scientific ESCALab 250Xi spectrometer with 200-W monochromatic Al Kα radiation. The 500 μm X-ray spot was used for small area XPS (SAXPS) analyses. The base pressure in the analysis chamber was about 3 × 10−9 mbar. Typically, the hydrocarbon C1s line at 284.8 eV from adventitious carbon was used for energy referencing. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) patterns were recorded on a Perkim-Elmer Diamond TGA apparatus under N2 atmosphere and a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Inductively Coupled Plasma Atomic Emission Spectrometer has been collected on a Agilent ICPOES730 apparatus. The amount of coke deposited on the catalyst has been calculated from ICP analysis. The catalyst surfaces were characterized by in-situ DRIFT under the reaction conditions using the BRUKER TENSOR II spectrometer. The catalyst was loaded into an in-situ cell fitted with ZnSe windows. Prior to any DRIFT experiment, the catalyst was reduced at 400 °C under a flow (20 mL min−1) of 50 % H2 in Ar for 1 h, and then purged with pure Ar for 0.5 h at the same temperature to remove hydrogen adsorbed on the catalyst. After the cell cooled down to room temperature, 100 ppm of CO balanced with Ar was fed into the cell at a flow rate of 20 mL min−1, and the IR spectra were collected after injecting the mixed gas for 0.5 h at 50 °C. 2.3 Dehydrogenation of n-butane The dehydrogenation of n-butane to n-butenes and 1,3-butadiene was carried out in a tubular quartz reactor (i.d.; 10 mm) at atmospheric pressure. An aliquot of the catalyst (0.10 g) was placed at the center of the reactor where the temperature was uniform. Butane balanced with Ar was continuously introduced into the reactor during the dehydrogenation process. Before n-butane dehydrogenation, the IM and EG catalysts need to be reduced with H2 atmosphere at at 400 °C for 1 h. The feed composition was fixed at n-butane: H2: Ar = 5: 1: 94 at a total flow rate of 50 mL min−1. The reaction temperature was measured using a thermocouple placed in the quartz reactor. The reaction products were analyzed by a gas chromatography (GC) with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). A KB-Al2O3/Na2SO4 column (50 m ×0.53 mm ×20 μm) and a packed column (13X molecular sieve) were used for the GC. The stream from the reactor was transported to the GC through a six-way valve. The temperature of the GC oven was initially set at 80 °C and then increased to 170 °C at 20 °C/min. The chromatograph was used to qualitatively determine the various products at different retention times with an external standard used for accurate quantitative results. All response factors of the target products and reactants were obtained using calibration gases. The conversions of n-butane to butenes and 1,3-butadiene and their selectivities were calculated on the basis of the carbon balance as follows: (1) C o n v e r s i o n % = F C 4 H 10 i n - F C 4 H 10 o u t F C 4 H 10 i n × 100 . (2) S e l e c t i v i t y % = n i [ F i ] o u t Σ n i × [ F i ] o u t × 100 . The turnover frequency (TOF) of n-butane in dehydrogenation reaction was calculated as: (3) T O F = F C4H10 in × conv . × M Pt m c a t × w P t × D P t where [FC4H10]in is the molar flow rate of n-butane in the feed (mol/s); conv. is the conversion of n-butane; M Pt is the atomic weight of platinum (195.08 g/mol); m cat is the weight of catalyst (g) used; w Pt is mass fraction of platinum and DPt is the dispersion of Pt particles. D Pt is the dispersion of Pt particles and was calculated by D Pt = 1.13/Pt particle size. The activation energy (Ea) was calculated by the Arrhenius equation: (4) k = a × exp ( − E a R T ) where a, R, and T are the pre-exponential factor, the universal gas constant, and the absolute temperature, respectively. The activation energy are researched with the conversions of n-butane lower than 10 %. 2.4 DFT calculations The plane-wave density functional theory was carried out by using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [1]. The electron-ion interactions was investigated by the projector augmented wave (PAW) method [2] and the exchange corrective interaction was described through the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the parametrization of Perde-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [3]. The plane wave basis energy cutoff was truncated at 400 eV. While performing the geometry optimization, the convergence criteria of energy and force were used as 1 × 10−5 eV/atom and 0.02 eV/Å, respectively. For searching the transition state, a force tolerance of 0.03 eV/Å and a total energy of 1 × 10-7 eV/atom were converged to obtain the accurate forces. Here, the increase in the super cell means a decrease in the coverage. Grids of 5 × 5×1, 5 × 3 × 1, 3 × 3 × 1, 3 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack K points were used for the calculations of surfaces (2ｘ2), (2ｘ3), (3ｘ4), and (4ｘ4), respectively. To avoid the interaction between the n-butane and the bottom of slab through periodic boundary, a 15 Å thickness vacuum was employed in the z direction. Further, the bottom of the two layers were fixed to simulate the bulk structure. The adsorption energy between the adsorbed atom (molecule) and the surface was defined as following: (5) E a = E t o t a l - E s u r f a c e - E a d s o r b a t e where E t o t a l , E s u r f a c e , and E a d s o r b a t e represent for the total energy of the system, the surface, and the adsorbate, respectively. In this work, the climbing-image nudge elastic band (CI-NEB) combined with the dimer method were implemented to search the saddle point. This has been proven to be one of the most efficient methods in searching transition state [4–6]. Importantly, after obtaining the so-called transition state, the harmonic vibrational frequency calculations had to be performed to ensure that it is the real transition state. The energy barrier was described as follows (6) E a = E t s - E i n where E t s and E i n stand for the total energies of the transition state and the initial state, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization 3.1.1 Physicochemical properties of the catalysts The surface areas of the catalysts prepared by the two methods are listed in Table 1 . The catalysts prepared by the ethylene glycol prereduction method exhibited a close BET surface area (370 m2 g−1); while the catalyst prepared by the impregnation method exhibited a slightly lower value. This could be due to the decrease in the total pore volume, as shown in Table 1. It has been reported that the impregnation method likely results in a poor distribution of Pt particles on the catalyst surfaces and could block the pores of support [20]. In addition, the average pore size for all the catalysts was similar. The contents of Pt (wt%) were around 0.81 wt% as determined by the ICP analysis. Besides, the value in IM-1 is slightly higher than that in EG samples. 3.1.2 X-ray diffractometry analysis The XRD patterns of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . All samples exhibit clear five diffraction peaks at 8.0°, 8.9°, 23.1°, 24.0°, and 24.4°, which are the characteristic peaks of TS-1 with a mordenite framework inversion (MFI) structure [21]. The sharp peaks indicate that the catalysts contain the highly crystalline TS-1 phase. No obvious XRD peaks of titanium were observed for all the catalysts, suggesting that titanium is incorporated in the lattice or is highly dispersed in the form of very small titania particles. In addition, the catalysts prepared by the ethylene glycol did not show any characteristic platinum peaks. The absence of the Pt reflections is most probably due to the presence of very small Pt particles [22,23]. In contrast, the pattern of the IM-1 catalyst displays a peak at 40.1°, which is the characteristic peak of Pt (111). This indicates a poorly dispersed or rather large size of metallic Pt particles. 3.1.3 Morphology TEM was used to observe the size distribution, of the Pt particles on the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 2 a, IM-1 contains particles with an average size of 5.62 nm. This figure shows poor dispersion of Pt species for the biggest particle size is bigger than 15 nm. By comparison, the Pt particle-size distributions on TS-1 prepared by ethylene glycol prereduction are shown in Figs. 2 b–d. The average size of Pt particles on sample by impregnation method is much larger than those prepared by the ethylene glycol prereduction method (1.81, 2.76, and 3.56 nm). These EG samples show good dispersion of Pt particles, which reveals uniform, nearly normally distributed sizes in the 1–4 nm range. These TEM figures is consistent with the XRD results, revealing the absence of large metal crystals in these samples [20]. Figs. 2 b–d suggest that, owning to the confinement effect of the preparation method, encapsulation inhibits the metal from further agglomerating into larger particles to a certain extent. 3.1.4 Surface valences Fig. 3 shows XPS Pt 4f spectra of IM-1 and EG-2. The Pt 4f XPS spectrum of IM-1 (Fig. 3a) shows peaks at 71.5 (Pt 4f7/2) and 74.6 eV (Pt 4f5/2) that are assigned to metallic Pt (Pt°) [28]. Fig. 3 b shows that EG-2 displays peaks at 72.1 and 75.5 eV which are more intense than the peaks in Fig. 3 a. The observed change in the peak position indicates that the electronic environments of the Pt particles on the catalysts prepared by the two methods are different. According to the literature, the XPS data reveal that the Pt in the EG-2 catalyst is in an electron-deficient state. This is attributable to strong interactions between the Pt species and Ti ions, with the Ti ions withdrawing electrons from the Pt species [29,30]. As shown in Fig. 4 , EG-2 and IM-1 catalysts contain Ti species in different chemical states; the binding energies of the Ti species in EG-2 are 464.8 and 459.1 eV, which are lower than those of IM-1 (465.5 and 459.6 eV). The DRIFT spectra for the adsorption of CO on reduced TS-1-based catalysts at room temperature (Fig. 5 ) show Pt-CO (2080 cm−1), Pt-CO-Pt (1850 cm−1), and Ti-CO (2170 cm−1) [31] peaks. Significantly, these peaks, which correspond to adsorbed CO, are quite different. There are mainly 4 bands of CO adsorbed on the Pt. CO bonded to Pt of IM sample produces a peak at 2080 cm−1, while CO bridge bonding on Pt clusters exhibits a broad resonance at 1880 cm−1. And the peak at 2170 cm−1 indicates the CO-Ti band strength. In EG samples, the absence of a broad band of 1800−1950 cm−1, which is corresponding to bridgebonded CO-Pt stretches, confirms a uniform dispersion of Pt. The peak at 2110 cm-1 indicates a linear CO-Pt stretch: a single atom Pt site. However, there is lack of enough characterization analysis to prove whether Pt is single atom or not. Another possible cause is the strong interaction between Pt and Ti in the support, the peak at 2110 cm-1 could be attributed to Ti-Pt-CO. [32] However, as shown in Fig. 5c, the peak at 2080 cm−1 is absent and the peak at 2114 cm−1 is quite strong which is attributed to the good dispersion of Pt particles and their small sizes [33]. 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Dehydrogenation of n-butane The activities of the catalyst for the dehydrogenation of n-butane were evaluated using a fixed-bed reactor connected to a gas chromatograph. The catalytic performance for n-butane dehydrogenation is shown in Fig. 6 as a function of the reaction temperature (300−580 °C). By comparison, the catalysts prepared by the traditional impregnation and the EG prereduction methods are researched by the same experimental conditions. As shown in Fig. 6 the conversion of n-butane was found to increase with increasing reaction temperature since n-butane dehydrogenation is thermodynamically limited and requires a high temperature to occur. The conversion of n-butane increased from a low temperature and then decreased as the temperature exceeded 500 °C, which is due to the formation of coke on the catalyst surfaces. The selectivities for trans-2-butene and cis-2-butene are quite close at about 37 %, and vary in a same way; i.e. decrease as the selectivity for 1,3-butadiene increases. Fig. 6 shows the differences observed between the catalysts prepared by the various methods. The selectivities of the EG catalyst for dehydrogenated products (1-butene, trans-2-butene, cis-2-butne, and 1,3-butadiene) are quite high (> 96 %) with few isomerized and hydrogenolysis products (C1–C3) observed. However, TS-1-supported Pt prepared by the EG prereduction was highly active, while the catalyst prepared by the impregnation method was poorly active. The conversions of n-butane on the catalysts prepared by the the EG prereduction method are higher than that of the catalyst prepared by the impregnation method. In addition, the selectivity of the IM catalyst for the dehydrogenated products (1-butene, trans-2-butene, cis-2-butne, and 1,3-butadiene) is about 88 % and the selectivity of C1–C3, which are the hydrogenolysis products, is about 12 %. 3.2.2 Stability testing the TS-1-based catalysts The n-butane conversions of the variously prepared TS-1-based catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 . The n-butane conversions of these catalysts slowly decrease with time on stream. The conversion of IM-1 decreased more obviously with time than the catalysts prepared by the EG prereduction method. The conversions of EG clearly higher than those of the IM catalyst. Among these catalysts, EG-2 exhibited the best catalytic activity and stability for conversion, with only a slightly decrease of conversion observed after 10 h on stream. As shown in Fig. S3, EG-2 sample shows the highest yield of all butenes at 500 °C. Since the trend for the selectivity of butenes on these samples are quite similar, the trend of butenes yield are almost same with that of n-butane conversion. Further research is required to obtain a better understanding of the reason for the superior stability of the catalysts prepared by the EG prereduction method. 3.3 Density functional theory calculations To gain a better understanding of the Pt particle size for tuning the conversion of n-butane, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed to investigate the reaction energy barrier for the first CH bond cleavage (dehydrogenation) of n-butane. The nano-catalysts with smaller Pt particle size show more active site in a certain area for size effect. We connect the Pt particle size with different molecules on the Pt surface. The adsorptions of n-butane on different surface coverages are investigated by locating the molecules on p(2 × 2), p(2 × 3), p(3 × 3), p(3 × 4) surfaces, respectively. The catalyst with the smallest Pt particle size means the most Pt (111) in a per unit area which is defined as the molecules on p(3 × 4) surfaces. And the final snapshots of n-butane adsorbed on the top slab are shown in Fig. 8 . According to Eq. (5), it is calculated that the adsorption energies are −0.08.−0.10, −0.09, and −0.09 eV, respectively. The energies indicate that the interactions between n-butane and surfaces are physisorption and the strength has no relationship with the surface coverage. The structure parameters of n-butane are listed in Table 2 . For n-butane on different coverages, all the lengths of the CC and C–H bonds in n-butane maintain at 1.52 and 1.10 Å, respectively. It is found the structure of the n-butane on the Pt(111) has no difference with the isolated n-butane (C-C: 1.52–1.53 Å, C–H: 1.10–1.11 Å), which confirms that the catalyst has no effect on the structure of n-butane. Usually, the formation process from n-butane to butyl suffers from two steps. The first step is the dehydrogenation in the methyl or methylene group of the n-butane and the second step is the formation of butyl via β–dehydrogenation. This was demonstrated in a number of studies that the dehydrogenation first H atom is from the top methyl group of n-butane. Thus in this calculation, we considered the transition state of dehydrogenation in the methyl group. The configurations of transition states on different coverages are shown in Fig. 9 . It is found that the active CH bonds fall in the range of 1.54–1.56 Å, which are elongated from 1.1 Å in gaseous n-butane. Moreover, the C-Pt distances for transition state are maintained at 2.27 Å, which are obviously closer than the ones for initial states. The phenomenon indicates that the formation of CPt bond weakens the CC bond in n-butane. 3.4 Discussion As mentioned above, catalysts prepared by the various methods show different catalytic activities. However, the intrinsic factors that influence the dehydrogenation process are unclear. Several reviews report that n-butane dehydrogenation is a structure-sensitive reaction [34,35]. Previous research showed that particle size and the distributions of active components affect catalytic activity. For example, Natarajan [36] reported that smaller Pt particles result in a higher catalytic activity for n-butane dehydrogenation. We used various methods to characterize our catalysts with the aim of elucidating the reason for their different catalytic activities. As shown in Table 1, the catalysts prepared by the ethylene glycol prereduction method have similar surface areas, average pore sizes, and pore volumes. To compare with IM sample, the surface areas and pore volumes of EG samples are slightly higher. This is possible because the pores in IM sample were blocked by some Pt species. For the pore volume of IM sample is smaller than that of TS-1 support. This is possibly due the pores of the catalysts prepared by the impregnation method being blocked by some Pt species [34,35]. However the values are close, which is in good agreement with the lack of obvious peaks corresponding to Pt particles in the XRD patterns of these catalysts. In order to further study the details of the Pt species, TEM images were acquired. As shown in Fig. 2, the Pt particles in the catalysts prepared by the ethylene glycol prereduction method were uniform in size and nearly normally distributed in the 1–3 nm range. More than 90 % Pt particle of the EG samples are between 1 and 3 nm while that of IM sample with a much wide distribution of 1 and 9 nm. Bsides, Pt dispersion has been improved via the pre-reduction method, it extremely increased from 35 % for IM-1 to 60 % for EG-2. Among these catalysts, EG-2 showed the smallest mean Pt size (1.81 nm) with dispersed Pt particles that are quite concentrated, which is consistent with the n-butane-dehydrogenation results. As mentioned above, catalysts with smaller Pt particles are more selective for butenes and butadiene [37]. As shown in Fig. 10 , the trans-butene and cis-butene selectivities are similar and do not vary with the particle size of Pt. These catalysts were analysed by XPS (Figs. 3 and 4) in order to determine other factors that influence the dehydrogenation process. The Pt 4f peak of the EG catalyst is observed at higher energy because Ti withdraws electrons form Pt. The IM-1 and EG-2 catalysts exhibit different Pt 4f and Ti 2p XPS peaks that reveal strong interactions between Pt and Ti species in the latter catalyst. Clearly, the Pt species in the two catalysts are different, with the Pt in EG-2 in an electron-deficient state. This may be responsible for the superior catalytic activity of the EG catalysts than that prepared by impregnation. However many reports on PtSn alloy-based catalysts show that electron-rich Pt particles favor the n-butane dehydrogenation reaction [38,39]. And some researchers have reported that TiO2-based catalysts exhibit good catalytic activities for superior n-butane adsorption [40]. The superior activity of the EG catalysts is attributed to the influence of Ti in the TS-1 structure. DRIFT spectra for the adsorption of CO on reduced Pt-TS-1-based catalysts were used to illustrate the state of Pt particles. As shown in Fig. 5, CO bridge bonding on Pt clusters exhibits a broad resonance at 1880 cm−1, was only observed in the spectrum of the IM catalyst [41]. By comparing the strength of peaks at 2110 cm−1, EG-2 sample which has the smallest Pt particle conforms the strongest strength.CO-atop adsorption is observed at higher wavenumber (2110 cm-1) for EG catalysts due to electron donation from Pt to Ti [42]. EG-2 shows the best catalytic activity for n-butane dehydrogenation may caused by the Pt which shows weakly electropositivity. However some reports interpret the peak at 2110 cm-1 to correspond to CO linearly absorbed on Ptδ+ single-atom sites on metal oxides [43]. However there is lack of enough characterization analysis to prove whether Pt is single atom or not. This is also possibly due to the smallest Pt particles leading to the strongest Pt/Ti interactions in the TS-1 support among the EG catalysts [23,29]. The strong metal-support interaction is helpful to improve the stability of catalysts [34]. It is worth pointing out that the CO-adsorption behavior is very consistent with how the initial activities of the catalysts depend on Pt particle size. The catalyst with smaller Pt particle size exhibit higher n-butane conversion and butenes selectivity. Although these values are a very rough approximation of the real TOF values of the catalyst, all the TOFs of EG samples are bigger than that of the IM-1 sample (428.4 h−1). Note that EG-2 exhibited not only the highest TOF (694.8 h−1) and good durability but also the highest n-butane conversion owing to the highest Pt dispersion. The trend of TOFs for n-butane dehydrogenation is close to the trend of reaction activation energy. The trend of reaction activation energy with Pt particle size are matched by the catalytic activity. As shown in Table. 3 , the reaction activation energy for dehydrogenation reaction on different catalysts are researched by changing the reaction temperature. The EG-2 shows the smallest reaction activation energy. It shows that catalyst with the smaller Pt particle size has the smaller reaction activation energy. The trend of reaction activation energy with Pt particle size are matched with the catalytic activity. The affect of Pt particle size are researched by changing the different n-butane coverage on the Pt surface. As mentioned in the density functional theory calculations, the catalyst with small Pt particle size means big n-butane coverage. Further the energy barriers for the first step activation of n-butane on different coverages are explored, which are shown in Fig. 11 . It is seen that the energy barrier decreases with increasing the supercell size. Thus, we conclude that the energy barrier of dehydrogenation could be weakened by increasing the coverage. The catalyst with the smallest particles shows the lowest energy barrier of the dehydrogenation process. This trend is consistent with the affect of particle size for the dehydrogenation reaction activity energy. 4 Conclusion Pt-TS-1-based catalysts prepared using the ethylene glycol prereduction method show quite good catalytic activities for n-butane dehydrogenation. The result exhibit selectivities above 97 % for butenes and butadiene, and a conversion of about 20 % at 500 °C over the EG-2 catalyst. In addition, this catalyst is very stable, with activity that was barely observed to decrease during dehydrogenation for 10 h. The catalysts were characterized to confirm that those prepared by the ethylene glycol prereduction method are superior. Ethylene glycol prereduction effectively reduces the average size of the Pt particles. And the distribution of Pt particle size are in a narrow area. As shown by TEM, the Pt particles are only 1.81 nm in size and are concentrated in the 1–2 nm range. Pt dispersion has been improved via pre-reduction method. Interestingly, Pt dispersion was extremely increased from 35 % for IM-1 to 60 % for EG-2. Strong metal-support interactions between the Pt species and the Ti species in the TS-1 support were observed by XPS and DRIFTS, which increase both catalytic activity and stability. The reaction activation energy for dehydrogenation reaction on different catalysts were decreased by decreasing the Pt particle size. The density functional theory calculations show that the energy barrier of dehydrogenation could be weakened by increasing the coverage of n-butane, which are belonged to the decreasing Pt particle size. coredata.dc:description: A series of catalysts in which platinum was supported on the crystalline pure titanium silicalite (TS-1) were prepared using two different loading methods, namely, an ethylene glycol (EG) reduction method and the conventional incipient wetness impregnation (IM) technique. Various characterization techniques were used to study the effect of the loading method on the physicochemical and morphological properties of the prepared catalysts. Also the effect of the platinum-loading method on the dehydrogenation of n-butane was investigated in a fixed-bed reactor. The results show that the EG method favors the formation of a more-concentrated Pt dispersion, which results in much better catalytic activities for the selective formation of butenes and butadiene (> 97 %). This phenomenon is interpreted by carrying out density functional theory (DFT) calculations with focus on the relationship between the coverage of n-butane on Pt surface and the activation barrier for the first CH bond cleavage.
coredata.dc:title: Pt/TS-1 catalysts: Effect of the platinum loading method on the dehydrogenation of n-butane
